user_message:
An agent A claimed that the following check_connection_reply code violates the MISRA C 2023 rule 2.2.
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<target_code>
Here is the original code of check_connection_reply.
```c
static void
check_connection_reply (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection; /**< a short alias */
  struct MHD_Response *const r = c->rp.response;  /**< a short alias */

  mhd_assert (c->rp.props.set);
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
  if ( (! c->rp.props.use_reply_body_headers) &&
       (0 != r->total_size) )
  {
    MHD_DLOG (c->daemon,
              _ ("This reply with response code %u cannot use reply body. "
                 "Non-empty response body is ignored and not used.\n"),
              (unsigned) (c->rp.responseCode));
  }
  if ( (! c->rp.props.use_reply_body_headers) &&
       (0 != (r->flags_auto & MHD_RAF_HAS_CONTENT_LENGTH)) )
  {
    MHD_DLOG (c->daemon,
              _ ("This reply with response code %u cannot use reply body. "
                 "Application defined \"Content-Length\" header violates"
                 "HTTP specification.\n"),
              (unsigned) (c->rp.responseCode));
  }
#else
  (void) c; /* Mute compiler warning */
  (void) r; /* Mute compiler warning */
#endif
}
```
</target_code>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- explanation: your evaluation of the scenario provided by the agent A.
- is_report_correct: whether the report is correct or not (true/false). True means there is a violation.
</response format>
<scenario>
The agent A provided the following violation scenario:
The initialization 'struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection;' is executed but can be unused: when the code is built without HAVE_MESSAGES the variable is not read (only cast to void), so the initialization has no effect. Removing the initialization would not change program behaviour in that build configuration — this is dead code and violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2. (If HAVE_MESSAGES is defined the alias is used, but the dead-code condition occurs for builds where HAVE_MESSAGES is not defined.)
</scenario>

<instruction>
Judge whether the report is correct or not.
</instruction>
explanation: The report is not correct. MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 explicitly states (note 3) that initialization is not the same as an assignment and is therefore not a candidate for dead code; an initializer that is executed cannot be flagged as dead code by this rule. Moreover, the initializations here are not pure no-ops: r is initialized from c->rp.response (and both initializers perform reads that could matter e.g. if members are volatile or if reading has timing/ordering implications), so removing them could change behaviour. The (void) c and (void) r lines are simply to suppress unused-variable warnings in the build without HAVE_MESSAGES. For these reasons the claimed violation is incorrect.
